Award.AwardTitle: Management and Operations of the Green Bank Observatory (GBO) and Long Baseline Observatory (LBO), amending AST-0956545, formerly entitled "Management and Operations of NRAO..."

ProgramElement.Text: GBO and LBO operations and mai

POR.DRECONTENT:
Associated Universities, Inc. submits this Project Outcomes report for AST-0956545, documenting the activities of the Green Bank Observatory (GBO) under the FY2017-2018 NSF-AUI Cooperative Agreement amendment AST-0836064 for the operation and management of GBO and LBO as extended by amendment AST-1838711 for FY2019. NRAO funding under AST-0956545 ended September 30, 2016.

The GBO is a world-class facility for science and engineering research located within two radio interference protection zones, the National Radio Quiet Zone (NRQZ) and the West Virginia Radio Astronomy Zone (WVRAZ). In addition to the 100m Robert C. Byrd Green Bank Telescope (GBT), the GBO operates a science and education center, an technology development center, and five radio telescopes ranging from 12m to 100m in diameter.

The GBT's 100m diameter collecting area, unblocked aperture, and excellent surface offer the scientific community unrivaled research capabilities at 0.1-116 GHz (3.0m-3.6mm wavelengths). The GBT is used by hundreds of scientists each year for research that spans every field of modern astrophysics. The GBT's collecting area and sensitivity provides excellent response to point sources. As a filled aperture, the GBT also offers the highest possible sensitivity to extended low surface-brightness emission. Scheduled dynamically to maximize its scientific output, the GBT was used for scientific research 6107, 6840, and 6789 hours in FY2017, FY2018, and FY2019, respectively.

The GBT instrument suite in FY2017-FY2019 consists of single/dual-pixel receivers from 300 MHz-96 GHz (non-contiguous), with four multipixel radio cameras. The GBT features industry-leading signal processing systems with a high dynamic range, state-of-the-art system for high time and frequency resolution observations, and the capability for very wide bandwidth (≥10 GHz) observations for spectral line and pulsar detection experiments.

The GBO supported a broad portfolio of education and public outreach programs that dramatically broadened the Observatory?s impact regionally and across North America. GBO education programs in Science, Technology, Education, and Mathematics provides hands-on research experiences for science and engineering educators and students. The multi-purpose Green Bank Science Center, visited by approximately 50,000 people each year, is where thousands of K-12 teachers and students participating in residential educational programs using the variety of radio telescopes available at the GBO.

The GBT contributed to many of the main scientific objectives from National Research Council's Astro2010 report, New Worlds, New Horizons in Astronomy and Astrophysics, including:

  • Gravitational Wave Astronomy: The GBT is at the forefront of Gravitational-wave astrophysics through high-precision timing of millisecond pulsars. These experiments are sensitive to gravitational radiation at nanoHertz frequencies which will originate from supermassive black hole binaries.
  • Origins: The spectral lines emitted by ionized, atomic, and molecular gas in star formation regions at high redshift fall within the GBT frequency coverage enhancing deciphering the origin of the first stars, galaxies, black holes, planetary systems, and even life itself.
  • Origin and Evolution of Galaxies: The GBT is being used as a highly efficient instrument to measure molecular lines and determine the redshift, gas mass, and kinematics of luminous sources that are likely proto-galaxies objects. The GBT adds enormous sensitivity at 3mm to long-baseline interferometer arrays, allowing imaging of radio jets close to the event horizon of the central black hole in galaxies.
  • Structure and Evolution of Galaxies in the Local Universe: GBT imaging of the neutral gas around nearby galaxies and the Milky Way provides otherwise-unattainable surface brightness sensitivity to faint hydrogen. The study of high velocity clouds in our Galaxy and in nearby galaxies is revolutionizing our understanding of the lifecycle of galaxies, and how gas flows relate to, and possibly drive, star formation. The GBT is reaching HI detection levels 10x more sensitive than other instruments.
  • Origin of Stars and Planets: The GBT is ideally suited for measuring physical conditions in infrared-dark clouds, the likely progenitors of stellar clusters. The GBT has been used to image and measure the temperature, density, turbulence, and kinematics of a large sample of dark clouds, providing new quantitative insights into star formation and the initial conditions that control dark cloud evolution.
  • Solar System: The GBT plays a major role in the study of our Solar System as a fundamental instrument for bi-static radar studies of asteroids and other Solar System bodies. Radar enables mapping of surface details with accuracies better, in some cases, than those achievable with an orbiter. Radar polarimetry can reveal properties of subsurface lunar rocks and geological features that are otherwise hidden.
  • Origins of Life: The GBT provides valuable data in answering the fundamental question of how life arose on Earth. A leader in this research, the GBT has detected many new organic molecules in space through its ability to measure weak, spatially extended spectral lines over a wide range of frequencies. Discoveries include the first interstellar chiral molecule, and an organic ring that may be the precursor of the ubiquitous interstellar polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons.
